Introduction

Rett syndrome is a rare neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by severe impairments in cognitive, motor, and communication skills that typically presents in the first 1-2 years of life after a period of normal development.  It is a genetic disorder caused primarily by mutations in the MECP2 gene and occurs predominantly in females.

Pathophysiology



Most cases of Rett syndrome result from mutations in the MECP2 gene that is expressed in all tissues, with an abundance in the brain.  The MECP2 gene encodes the MeCP2 protein, which is involved in the epigenetic regulation of several target genes, particularly those critical to neuronal development.  Pathogenic MECP2 variants contribute to impaired synaptic maturation and cortical maintenance, resulting in arrested brain development without neuronal death.  Therefore, the condition is considered a neurodevelopmental disorder (ie, symptoms manifest due to disrupted brain growth and development) rather than a neurodegenerative disorder (ie, symptoms manifest due to progressive neuronal damage/loss).



In the vast majority of cases, Rett syndrome occurs sporadically due to a de novo mutation in MECP2, which is located on the X chromosome.  Rett syndrome appears to affect almost exclusively females, which may be explained by the following:



  • De novo MECP2 gene mutations appear to occur almost solely on the paternally-derived X chromosome.  Therefore, males (whose single X chromosome is maternally derived) do not generally develop a de novo mutation.
  • Due to the critical role of MECP2, many males who develop an MECP2 mutation succumb to early lethality.  In contrast, a mutation in females (46,XX) is not rapidly fatal because they have some functional MECP2 from the corresponding normal X chromosome.  Therefore, it is almost always females who survive to develop Rett syndrome.

Clinical presentation



For the first 6 months of life, individuals with Rett syndrome typically have normal development.  The earliest indicator of Rett syndrome may be a deceleration in head circumference.  After age 6 months (particularly around 12-18 months), patients begin developing features of Rett syndrome, which may include:



  • Regression of verbal communicative skills (eg, using facial expressions or single words only);  often occurs gradually but can sometimes be rapidly progressive (over the course of days)
  • Loss of purposeful hand movements (eg, twisting of fingers, inability to feed self, stereotypical movements [hair pulling])
  • Gait abnormalities (eg, lurching gait)
  • Decelerated growth (initially in head circumference, followed by height and weight; the brain stops growing after age 4)  may be exacerbated by oropharyngeal dysfunction contributing to inadequate nutritional intake
  • Seizures
  • Abnormal autonomic nervous system regulation (contributing to cardiac electrical instability and a characteristic pattern of disordered breathing consisting of alternating episodes of hyperventilation and hypoventilation)
  • Sleep disturbances (eg, waking up screaming)
  • Autistic features (eg, lack of eye contact and social reciprocity)

Differential diagnosis



Several other conditions may have overlapping features with Rett syndrome, including:

Diagnostic evaluation



Diagnosis of Rett syndrome is based on clinical and genetic features.  In patients with clinical features suggestive of Rett syndrome, diagnostic evaluation should include MECP2 gene analysis.  A diagnosis is made if an MECP2 mutation is found in patients with characteristic clinical features.  Other studies to consider in the work-up of patients with developmental delay but normal MECP2 gene may include gene analysis for other genetic disorders, MRI of the brain to evaluate for structural abnormalities, and serum amino acids and urine organic acids to evaluate for an inborn error of metabolism.

Prognosis



After the initial presentation, patients with Rett syndrome generally have a period of rapid regression in the first few years of life.  After this, there is a period of stability consisting of relative preservation of acquired skills, which can last several years.  Patients may recover some nonverbal communication during this time.  After age 10, motor skills may progressively worsen, manifesting as reduced strength and mobility with increased rigidity.  Scoliosis is common as patients reach adolescence.



Many patients survive into adulthood with a median survival until approximately age 45.  However, their quality of life may be significantly impaired, particularly in those with frequent seizures, difficulty with ambulation, and respiratory difficulties (a common cause of death in affected patients).

Management



Management of Rett syndrome is primarily supportive and aimed at addressing symptoms and improving quality of life.  This may include:



  • Physical, occupational, and speech therapy to address motor and communication difficulties
  • Behavioral therapy to address sleep and behavioral challenges
  • Antiepileptic medications to control seizures
  • Nutritional support to improve growth
  • Management of scoliosis


Disease-modifying therapies (eg, trofinetide, a synthetic analogue of a naturally-occurring peptide) are also being developed to treat some of the symptoms (eg, abnormal breathing, nighttime behaviors, repetitive behaviors) seen in Rett syndrome.

Summary



Rett syndrome (
